Hospitalization Record.Chief Complaint: Blurred vision and severe headache for 3 days

Present Illness.Onset: Three days ago at home, sudden onset with no prodromal symptoms. Possible trigger unknown.
Present Illness.Main Symptoms: Blurred vision in both eyes, severe headache rated 8/10, persistent for 3 days, worsened by dim light, not relieved by over-the-counter analgesics.
Present Illness.Accompanying Symptoms: Eye swelling, eye pain, nausea, vomiting, foggy vision, unequal pupil sizes, and decreased vision.
Present Illness.Diagnosis and Treatment History: Visited an urgent care center two days ago, prescribed eye drops and analgesics with no significant improvement.
Present Illness.General Condition Changes: Mental state anxious due to persistent symptoms; sleep normal but disturbed by pain, appetite decreased, normal urination and defecation, slight weight loss noted.

Personal History.Exposure History: No exposure to industrial toxins, dust, radioactive substances, etc.

Marital and Family History.Family History: Parents healthy, no history of eye diseases in siblings

Systematic Examination.Chest: Normal, lungs clear, heart sounds normal
Systematic Examination.Abdomen: Soft, non-tender, liver and spleen not palpable
Systematic Examination.Limbs: No edema, full range of motion
Systematic Examination.Nervous System: Cranial nerves intact, no focal deficits

Hospitalization Record.Specialist Examination: Ophthalmology: Elevated intraocular pressure noted, cup-to-disc ratio increased, visual field test shows peripheral vision loss.
Hospitalization Record.Auxiliary Examination: Tonometry showing elevated intraocular pressure at 28 mmHg. Gonioscopy confirming closed angles. Visual field test indicating peripheral vision loss.
Hospitalization Record.Diagnostic Basis: Based on history of sudden vision change, eye pain, elevated intraocular pressure, visual field loss, and examination findings.
Hospitalization Record.Differential Diagnosis: Acute iridocyclitis and acute conjunctivitis ruled out by lack of photophobia and discharge. Acute gastroenteritis and neurological diseases ruled out by ocular findings.

Post-Admission Course Records.First Course Record: Admitted with acute angle-closure glaucoma, started on mannitol IV and acetazolamide to lower intraocular pressure. Scheduled for emergency laser peripheral iridotomy.
Post-Admission Course Records.Daily Course Records: Day 1 post-surgery: no complications noted, intraocular pressure decreased to 18 mmHg. Pain and vision improving. Continue monitoring and medications.
Post-Admission Course Records.Senior Physician Rounds Records: Reviewed patient on morning rounds, stable post-op, plan to continue current management and re-evaluate in 24 hours.
Post-Admission Course Records.Handover Records: Patient stable, no new issues overnight. Continue with postoperative care and monitoring.
Post-Admission Course Records.Stage Summary: At the end of week 1: Patient responding well to treatment, intraocular pressure stable. Discharge planned for tomorrow with follow-up in ophthalmology clinic.

Surgery Related.Preoperative Summary: Confirmed diagnosis of acute angle-closure glaucoma, decided on laser peripheral iridotomy.
Surgery Related.Preoperative Discussion Records: Discussed benefits and risks of surgery, potential for persistent high intraocular pressure or need for further surgery.
Surgery Related.Anesthesia Preoperative Visit Records: Patient evaluated and cleared for local anesthesia with sedation.
Surgery Related.Anesthesia Records: Local anesthesia with sedation administered, patient tolerated well.
Surgery Related.Surgery Records: Laser peripheral iridotomy performed without complications, intraocular pressure reduced post-op.
Surgery Related.Surgery Safety Checklist: Completed, all items verified and confirmed.
Surgery Related.Surgery Instrument Count Records: All instruments accounted for post-surgery, no discrepancies.
Surgery Related.Postoperative First Course Record: Patient stable, intraocular pressure decreased, pain controlled, no immediate complications.
Surgery Related.Anesthesia Postoperative Visit Records: Patient recovering well from anesthesia, normal vital signs, no adverse effects noted.

Post-Admission Course Records.Discharge Records: Patient discharged on 15th April with instructions for medications and follow-up in 1 week.

Medical Orders.Temporary Orders: Mannitol IV PRN for elevated intraocular pressure

Hospitalization Record.Temperature Chart: T: 36.8°C, P: 78 bpm, R: 16 bpm, BP: 120/80 mmHg
Hospitalization Record.Special Examination Consent: Consent obtained for diagnostic tonometry and gonioscopy

Diseases of the Eye and Adnexa.Name: Glaucoma
Diseases of the Eye and Adnexa.Symptoms: Blurred vision, headache, eye swelling, eye pain, nausea, vomiting, foggy vision, unequal pupil sizes, decreased vision
Diseases of the Eye and Adnexa.Differential Diagnosis: Acute angle-closure glaucoma acute attack, accompanied by severe headache, nausea, vomiting, etc., may be misdiagnosed as acute gastroenteritis and neurological diseases; acute iridocyclitis, acute conjunctivitis.
